section.title: Description
section.paragraph: This element defines output for MTS or mIRC startup.
This element is optional and may appear only once per scheme.

attributes.attribute: The color to be used when the engine /echos the data.
The amount of indent the engine should use when the data is wrapped.
The window in which the data should be displayed. May be a window name or a keyword (see below) and multiple keywords may be used.
The name of the resource sound file to be played when the event is triggered.
Whether or not the engine should halt output for this event.

keywords.keyword: Sends output to the active window, regardless of which connection triggered the output
Sends output to all channels on the active connection
Sends output to all channels on the connection where the output was triggered
Sends output to all channels on all connections
Sends output to the status window of the active connection
Sends output to the status window of the connection that triggered the output
Sends output to all status windows
Sends output to the status window and all channels of the active connection
Sends output to the status window and all channels on the connection that triggered the output
Sends output to all channel and status windows

section.title: Data
section.paragraph: Text, mIRC control codes and identifiers and constant keywords.
Multiple line entries are supported and will be displayed as individual lines.

section.title: Engine Requirements
section.paragraph: The color, indent and target attributes should be evaluated and inserted into the /echo command in the proper place. When a keyword is used in the target attribute, the engine should process the keyword as specified (see the "Keywords" section for the target attribute).
Multiple lines should be displayed individually, each line retaining the settings specified in the color, indent and target attributes.
If the halted attribute is set to true, the engine should evaluate the text contained within the event but NOT display it.
The text contained within this element should be evaluated and displayed whenever the MTS engine is started or when mIRC first opens (with the 'on start' event)
